until the fifteenth century, the Mongol Road that superseded the Buddhist Road was maintained by Mongol states for their couriers and troops, as well as for the artists, scholars, and merchants they summoned to their separate courts.

We would have liked to include a chapter on the Sogdian Road because it provides another example of a Silk Road network. The East Iranian merchants who maintained it had colonies and settlements from the Korean border to Byzantium and Europe. For more information on the Sogdian Road, see Etienne de la Vaissière, Sogdian Traders: A History, Handbook of Oriental Studies

Mount Meru is also featured on the robe of a specific type of buddha identified as either Vairocana or the Cosmological Buddha.

The idea of mapping the universe onto a person's body is rooted in the ancient Indian concept of the primordial or cosmic man (puruṣa) eulogized in Vedic literature, and in the depiction of Viṣṇu in Hindu art.
Among extant examples of Khotanese mural paintings there is an example of Vairocana, whose body is adorned with images of Mount Meru (or symbolically the Mount Meru throne) and other cosmic emblems.
This celebrated event is depicted in early Buddhist art, such as on a pillar of the north gateway of Sāñcī Stūpa I, dating to the first century bce.

The absence of an image of the Buddha has been ascribed to the 'aniconic phase' of early Buddhist art. Alternately, some art historians argue that such a depiction does not portray the Buddha's presence but commemorates the sacred site.

Ancient art often represents the zodiac as a circle or a ring, often bearing the images of the zodiacal signs. This standard iconographical pattern needed no explicit inscriptions or symbols.

citations.text: This chapter is devoted to a close analysis of this cultural contact with East Asia by examining in depth a number of oriental motifs only casually described in earlier literature.
citations.context: A part of the research and the illustrative material was realized thanks to successive grants from the Bertha and John Garabedian Charitable Foundation of Fresno, California.

citations.text: At a conference in 1977, I gave a paper entitled 'Far Eastern Influences in Armenian Miniature Painting in the Mongol Period.'
citations.context: This paper was part of a panel on 'Patronage and Symbolism in Medieval Armenian Art,' sponsored by the Society for Armenian Studies during the Eleventh Annual Meeting of the Middle East Studies Association in New York.

The labels at the center of the page refer to Hindu cities along the banks of the Ganges, such as Benares, Prayâg, and, most prominently, Qanawdj.
Today Qanawdj lies in the Farrukhhâbâd district of present-day Uttar Pradesh. Tripathi 1959: 3; Dames and Burton-Page 1978.
army consists of twenty-five hundred elephants.
The middle of India is the country round Qanawdj, which they call Madhyadeša, i.e., the middle of the realm.
al-Bîrûnî portrays the geography of India as a list of routes connecting the city with the different parts of India.
In pre-Islamic Buddhist sources, there is frequent reference to the important trade route that proceeded from the Indus delta.
Early Islamic geographers attest to the continuous use of this desert route through Mathura, notwithstanding the Muslim conquest of Sind.
The author of the Hudûd al-'âlam mentions that the merchandise of India is brought to Arûr and other small towns.
By the eleventh century, however, Multân had become the western terminus point of the desert route coming from the Gangetic valley.
which is probably Dhavalpur or Dûpâlpâr, modern Dholpur, on the Bîâh tributary of the Indus.
The fifth label, which reads Bânâshwar, is probably the city of Thaneswar or Thânesar, famed for its Hindu shrine.
which is possibly a gross corruption of Mathûra, noted by other medieval sources as the chief entrepot.
The second section of the itinerary is entitled 'The Road to China from [Qanawdj]'
Evidence, mainly from non-Muslim sources, suggests that the ancient overland passage from India to China through Assam and Myanmar emerged.
From there various routes led to Myanmar and Yunnan, in southwestern China.
It was established in the mid-seventh century and acquired a short-lived importance from the mid-ninth to the mid-tenth century.
al-Bîrûnî describes a third eastern route from Qanawdj toward Assam, and then relates an account of a traveler.
The author of the Hudûd al-'âlam also describes a river crossing at the Sino-Tibetan border, a sign of some knowledge.

Occasionally, they are found on thirteenth- and fourteenth-century Ilkhanid miniatures and ceramics, and even on pre-Ilkhanid book illustrations from northern Iraq, Anatolia, or Iran.
In pre-Ilkhanid times, the motif of a spotted horse appears more often on objects such as bowls, plates, and bottles.
Spotted horses as an iconographic motif reached the Iberian Peninsula as early as the tenth century. From Islamic objects of art the motif moved into illustrations of Castilian literature.
Other examples of spotted horses are present in Chinese paintings copying a so-called Central Asian style.
The Khotanese horse is linked to Seljuq and Ilkhanid piebald horses through its knotted tail, a feature missing in the Catalan Atlas.
This kind of tail can be found in numerous portraits of dromedaries on miniatures-for instance, in late-thirteenth-century manuscripts of al-Hariri's Maqamat.
donkey-)like tails are much rarer but can be found on plates and bowls.
They can be seen much more often and clearly in Timurid and Safavid miniatures.
It has been assumed that the motif of spotted and brightly colored horses in the Catalan Atlas came from Andalusian, Fatimid, Abbasid, or Seljuq art objects.
Pre-Ilkhanid piebald horses do not show small circles or dots but flowerlike images or larger blotches of irregularly curved shape.
Piebald horses in Ilkhanid manuscripts are often depicted with regular small circles. The color of the horses ranges from black and brown to a bright red.
Piebald horses in late and post-Ilkhanid manuscripts are adorned with tiny dots and appear mostly in light blue, pink, white, or black.

Alternative sources of inspiration may have come from Islamic cultures around the Mediterranean Sea. Examples are ceramic dishes, which were occasionally used as decoration on the outer walls of churches in Pisa, Genoa, and other towns in Italy, Sicily, and further Mediterranean islands, as well as glass and metal objects.

For Türkmän, see Peter B. Golden, An Introduction to the History of the Turkic Peoples: Ethnogenesis and State-Formation in Medieval and Early Modern Eurasia and the Middle East, Turcologica vol. 9 (Wiesbaden: Harrassowitz, 1992), 212.

summary.abstract: This edited volume examines the transmission and transformation of maps and geographical images across the Silk Road from antiquity through the medieval period. Drawing on contributions from scholars of Islamic studies, Chinese history, Buddhist art, and cartography, the book argues that spatial concepts—including cosmological diagrams, astronomical representations, and geographical depictions—traveled alongside merchants and pilgrims, influencing diverse intellectual and artistic traditions from Arabic astronomy to Armenian manuscripts to Chinese landscape painting. The collection demonstrates that maps and images functioned not as objective representations but as culturally contingent visual and textual artifacts that were adapted, reinterpreted, and integrated into local knowledge systems across Eurasia.
